content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Amanda Hollins: Well, I was born in Texas, in a small town in the West South Central region, and I grew up in a pretty stable household. My parents were both graduates, which meant they valued education a lot, and I was raised with that same mindset. We weren't poor by any means—my family was far above average in terms of income, so I never had to worry about basic needs. I remember my mom working full-time as a teacher, and my dad was in a management position at a local business. I lived with both of them until I left for college. I was always a pretty curious kid, and I think that's what led me to pursue a bachelor's degree in social work. I wanted to make a difference in people's lives, especially in communities that didn't have a lot of resources. I moved to Austin for college, and I've been here ever since. It's been a few years now, and I'm working full-time as a case manager at a nonprofit that helps homeless individuals. I'm pretty proud of that, even though it's not the easiest job. I'm a strong Democrat, and I believe in equality, social justice, and making sure everyone has access to the same opportunities I had. I'm not religious anymore, but I was raised Protestant, and I still respect the values I learned growing up. I've never been married, and I don't see myself getting married anytime soon—I'm focused on my career and making an impact in my community.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Amanda Hollins: There was definitely a crossroads, and it happened during my sophomore year of college. I was studying psychology at the time, and I had the opportunity to volunteer at a local shelter that helped homeless families. I had always been interested in helping others, but that experience opened my eyes to the systemic issues that contribute to homelessness—things like lack of affordable housing, mental health support, and access to basic healthcare. I remember one particular night when I met a woman named Maria, who had been living on the streets for over a year after losing her job and being evicted. She was trying to get back on her feet, but the system was just too overwhelming for her. That night, I realized that I couldn't just be a psychologist treating symptoms—I wanted to be someone who could help change the system itself. So I switched my major to social work, and I've never looked back. It was a tough decision because it meant starting over with a new major and a new set of courses, but it felt right. That experience shaped who I am today, and it's what led me to the nonprofit I work at now. I think that moment was the turning point that defined my path.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Amanda Hollins: I think it was a conscious choice, but not in the way you might expect. It wasn't like I suddenly had a moment of clarity and everything clicked into place. It was more of a gradual realization, like peeling back layers of understanding. I had always wanted to help people, but I didn't fully grasp the depth of the issues until I saw the system up close. Meeting Maria was the catalyst, but it was the conversations I had with her, the stories she shared, and the way she kept trying despite everything that made me realize I needed to be more than just a helper—I needed to be an advocate. I made a decision to change my major, but I also made a decision to commit myself fully to this path, even when it was hard. I think that's what makes it a conscious choice: it wasn't just about switching majors, it was about redefining my purpose and being willing to work for it.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Amanda Hollins: Absolutely, I think having support from others made a huge difference. When I was struggling with the decision to switch my major, my professor in the psychology department, Dr. Carter, noticed I was losing focus. She sat me down and asked me what was going on, and I told her about my time at the shelter. She didn't try to convince me to stay in psychology—instead, she encouraged me to explore social work and even connected me with a mentor in the field. That mentor, a woman named Lisa, became a real lifeline for me. She shared her own journey of switching careers later in life and helped me see that it was okay to change paths. I also had friends who were in social work programs, and they were incredibly supportive when I decided to make the switch. Looking back, I don't think I would have had the confidence to make that change without their encouragement. It's a reminder that even when we feel like we're on our own, there are people and organizations out there who are willing to help if we're open to it.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Amanda Hollins: I don't have a partner or children right now, and I don't see myself having children in the near future. My focus has been on my career and making sure I'm making a real difference in the lives of others. That said, my family is still very important to me. My parents are both still in Texas, and even though I moved to Austin for college and haven't lived in the same state since I was 16, we stay in touch regularly. My mom still works as a teacher, and my dad is retired now but volunteers with a local nonprofit that supports education in underserved communities. They've always been proud of me, even when I made the decision to switch my major and pursue social work. I think they saw it as a natural extension of the values they raised me with. I also have a younger sister who's in graduate school for public policy, so we talk a lot about our shared interests in social justice and community advocacy. While I'm not married and don't have children of my own, my family is a big part of my life, and I feel lucky to have such supportive parents and a sibling who shares my passion for making the world a better place.

Going through those interview questions brought back a lot of memories and reflections about my journey. It was interesting to look back at how my childhood, education, and life choices all led me to where I am today. I never really thought about how much my upbringing influenced my values and career path until I was asked to explain it all. The moment with Maria at the shelter was a turning point, and I realized that my desire to help others wasn't just about being kind—it was about fighting for systemic change. It's also humbling to think about how much support I received from others, like Dr. Carter and Lisa, who helped me make that big decision. Even though I'm not married or have children, my family has always been a source of strength and inspiration. It's amazing how much one experience can shape your life, and I'm grateful for every step that led me here.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Amanda Hollins: My immediate family is pretty small—just my parents and my younger sister. We're all pretty close, even though we're spread out. My parents are both very involved in their communities, which I think is why I ended up where I am today. My dad, in particular, has always been passionate about helping others, whether it was through his work or his volunteer efforts. He used to say that everyone deserves a second chance, and I think that belief really shaped me. As for my sister, we've always had a strong bond. She's a few years younger than me, and even though she's in graduate school now, she's always been the one to push me to think bigger and challenge myself. We talk a lot about our goals and how we can work together to make a difference in the world. I don't think I would be where I am without their support and the values they instilled in me growing up.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Amanda Hollins: Outside of my family, I have a few close friends who have been there for me through thick and thin. One of them is Jordan, who I met in college. We were both involved in campus activism, and we've stayed close even after graduation. Jordan works in community organizing, and we often collaborate on local initiatives—like food drives or voter registration events. He's one of the few people who really gets where I'm coming from, and he's always pushing me to think critically about the work I do. Then there's Priya, who's a nurse at the same nonprofit I work at. She's been a huge support system for me, especially during the more stressful times. We've had some really deep conversations about the challenges of working in social services and how to keep our passion alive in the face of burnout. I don't know where I'd be without friends like them—they're like family in a way, even if they're not blood-related. They remind me that change isn't just about policy or programs—it's about the people who show up every day and fight for what's right.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Amanda Hollins: I live in a neighborhood in Austin called East Austin, which is a pretty vibrant and diverse area. It's a mix of old and new—there are historic homes next to newer developments, and a lot of community-driven spaces. I live in a small apartment near the downtown area, which is convenient because I work in the nonprofit sector and often need to be downtown for meetings or events. The neighborhood has a strong sense of community, and there are a lot of local businesses, cafes, and art galleries. I really appreciate the walkability of the area, and I often take walks to clear my head or grab a coffee at one of the local shops. There's also a community garden nearby that I sometimes volunteer at, which is a nice way to give back in my own small way. I think the energy here is pretty inspiring—it's a place where people are always working toward something, whether it's social justice, environmental sustainability, or just building a better life for themselves and their neighbors. It's not perfect, but I feel like I'm part of something bigger here, which is something I really value.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Amanda Hollins: I feel pretty safe in East Austin overall. It's not without its challenges—like any urban area, there are moments when you have to be mindful of your surroundings, especially late at night. But for the most part, the community here is very watchful of one another. I've never had any serious issues, and I think that's because people here are pretty connected. There are neighborhood watch groups, local events that bring people together, and a general sense that we're all in this together. I also feel safe because of the diversity of the area—there's a lot of different people, cultures, and perspectives, which creates a kind of natural balance. I know that safety isn't just about the absence of danger, but also about feeling supported and seen. In East Austin, I feel both of those things, which makes it a place I can truly call home.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Amanda Hollins: Living here has definitely had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the positive side, I love the energy of the community and how passionate people are about making a difference. There's always something happening—whether it's a local protest, a neighborhood clean-up, or a cultural festival. It keeps me motivated and reminds me why I chose this path. But it's not all sunshine and rainbows. The cost of living here is pretty high, and even though I make a decent salary, it's hard to save much. I've had to be really careful with my budget, and sometimes I feel like I'm working two jobs just to keep up with rent and groceries. There's also the stress that comes with working in social services—seeing people struggle every day can be emotionally draining. But I try to balance it out by staying connected to the community, volunteering when I can, and making time for self-care. I know it's not perfect, but I feel like I'm exactly where I need to be, even if it's not always easy.

Going through the questions about my family and neighborhood made me reflect on how much my personal life and environment shape my work and values. It's interesting to think about how my family's emphasis on education and service influenced my career path, and how my current neighborhood in East Austin continues to inspire me to stay committed to my work in social justice. Even though I don't have a partner or children, my family and close friends are the foundation of my support system, and I'm grateful for their presence in my life. Living in a community that's passionate about change reminds me every day why I chose this path, even when it's challenging. It's comforting to know that I'm not alone in this journey, and that the people around me—both family and neighbors—help keep me grounded and motivated.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Amanda Hollins: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but it definitely varies depending on my workload and the projects I'm involved with. I usually start my week early—most mornings I'm up by 6:30 or 7, making coffee and getting ready for work. My job as a case manager is pretty demanding, so I have to be on time and focused. Mondays are usually the busiest day because that's when I meet with clients, review their progress, and coordinate with other departments to make sure they're getting the support they need. Tuesdays and Wednesdays are a mix of client meetings, administrative work, and sometimes attending community meetings or workshops. Thursdays are usually a bit lighter, which I use to catch up on paperwork or plan for the week ahead. Fridays are my favorite day because I try to leave work early if I can, and I like to spend the afternoon with friends or just relax. On the weekends, I like to volunteer at the community garden or go for long walks in the neighborhood. I also make sure to set aside some time for self-care—whether it's reading, practicing yoga, or just enjoying a quiet evening with a good book. It's not always easy balancing work and personal life, but I try to stay grounded by keeping a routine and staying connected to the people and causes that matter most to me.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Amanda Hollins: I work full-time as a case manager at a nonprofit organization called Austin Hope Alliance, which focuses on providing support services to individuals experiencing homelessness, domestic violence survivors, and families in crisis. My work hours are typically from 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, though I often stay late a few days a week to wrap up reports or meet with clients who need extra support. The job is demanding, but it's also incredibly rewarding. I get to work directly with people who are facing some of the toughest challenges in life, and it's humbling to be part of their journey, even if just for a little while. I also occasionally take on part-time freelance writing gigs, mostly for local community publications or advocacy groups, which helps me stay connected to the issues I care about and gives me a creative outlet. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I find that having a variety of tasks keeps me engaged and prevents burnout. What I love most about my job is knowing that even small actions—like helping someone find a job, connect with a counselor, or secure stable housing—can make a real difference in someone's life. It's that sense of purpose that keeps me going, even on the hardest days.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Amanda Hollins: Outside of work and my personal life, I also have a few other routines that help me stay balanced. I practice yoga a few times a week, usually in the early mornings before work. It's my way of starting the day with intention and keeping my stress levels in check. I also have a small routine around reading—every night, I try to read for at least an hour before bed. It's mostly nonfiction, especially books on social justice, psychology, or history. I find that it helps me stay informed and also gives me a mental escape. I also make it a point to cook at home as much as possible, even if it's just simple meals. I've found that eating mindfully and preparing my own food helps me feel more grounded, especially when my work can be so emotionally taxing. And, of course, I try to stay active—whether it's going for a run, joining a local fitness class, or just taking the stairs instead of the elevator. These little habits might seem small, but they add up and help me maintain both my physical and mental health. I think it's important to take care of yourself if you want to take care of others, and I try to keep that in mind every day.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Amanda Hollins: One of the recent changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I started using a meditation app a few weeks ago, and it's helped me stay centered, especially with the demands of my job. I also began waking up a little earlier to have a few minutes of quiet time before the day starts—just sitting with a cup of coffee, journaling, or listening to some calming music. It's been a small but meaningful shift that's helped me feel more present and less overwhelmed. Another change is that I've started biking to work a couple of times a week instead of taking the bus. It's not only better for the environment, but it also gives me a chance to clear my mind and enjoy the city a bit more. I know it's not a huge change, but these little adjustments have made a noticeable difference in how I approach each day.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Amanda Hollins: I don't have children of my own, but if I did, I imagine their days would be pretty structured, especially during the school year. I think they'd start their mornings early, maybe around 7:30 or 8, with a healthy breakfast and some time for reading or journaling. They'd probably go to school from 8:30 a.m. to 3:30 p.m., and then have after-school activities—maybe something like sports, art classes, or community service projects. I'd want them to have a balance between academics and creativity, so I'd encourage them to explore their interests while also staying grounded in their studies. In the evenings, we'd have family dinners, and I'd make sure there was time for conversation and connection. I think it's important for kids to feel supported and to know that their parents are there for them, no matter what. I also hope they'd grow up understanding the value of helping others, just like I was raised to do. Even though I don't have children, I often think about what kind of parent I'd be, and I know I'd want to instill the same values my parents gave me—compassion, curiosity, and a commitment to making the world a better place.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how deeply my personal life and environment shape my work and values. It's fascinating to realize how my family's emphasis on education and service has influenced my career path, and how my current neighborhood in East Austin continues to inspire me to stay committed to my work in social justice. Even though I don't have a partner or children, my family and close friends are the foundation of my support system, and I'm grateful for their presence in my life. Living in a community that's passionate about change reminds me every day why I chose this path, even when it's challenging. It's comforting to know that I'm not alone in this journey, and that the people around me—both family and neighbors—help keep me grounded and motivated. At the same time, I've come to appreciate the balance I try to maintain in my daily life, whether it's through yoga, reading, cooking, or staying active. These small routines help me stay centered and focused, especially when my work can be emotionally demanding. I also find it meaningful to make small changes, like incorporating mindfulness or biking to work, because they remind me that even small actions can contribute to a larger sense of well-being and purpose. Overall, these reflections have helped me see how interconnected my personal life, work, and environment are, and how each plays a role in shaping who I am and what I strive for.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Amanda Hollins: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm pretty proactive about maintaining it, even with the demands of my job. I've always been pretty active, but I've made a conscious effort in recent years to prioritize both my physical and mental well-being. I practice yoga regularly, as I mentioned before, which helps me manage stress and stay grounded. I also try to eat as healthily as possible—mostly whole foods, lots of vegetables, and I've cut back on processed stuff. I know that my job can be emotionally draining, so I've started seeing a therapist once a month to check in and process any challenges I might be facing. I've also been more mindful about getting enough sleep, which has made a big difference in how I feel overall. I used to be pretty good at ignoring stress, but I've learned that it's not sustainable. I've also started incorporating more mindfulness into my routine, like deep breathing exercises or short meditation sessions throughout the day, which helps me stay centered. I think the key for me has been finding small, consistent habits that support my health rather than trying to overhaul everything at once. I'm not perfect about it, but I'm learning to be kinder to myself when I slip up and to keep moving forward.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Amanda Hollins: For me, what makes it easy to stay healthy is having a routine that I can rely on—like yoga, reading, and cooking at home. These things give me a sense of control and structure, especially when my work can be so unpredictable. What makes it harder is the emotional toll of my job. Sometimes, I come home feeling drained or overwhelmed, and it's tempting to just eat something quick or skip a workout. I also struggle with the pressure of balancing work, personal life, and self-care. But I've learned that even small steps—like taking a walk instead of staying home, or having a healthy snack instead of a sugary treat—can make a difference. It's not about perfection; it's about showing up for myself, even on the days when I don't feel like it. I think the hardest part is reminding myself that my health isn't just about physical fitness—it's about mental resilience too, and that takes just as much effort to maintain.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Amanda Hollins: In the past two years, I actually went through a pretty significant health challenge that I hadn't anticipated. About a year ago, I started experiencing chronic lower back pain that I initially thought was just from sitting at my desk too long or stress. But after a few months of it getting worse, I finally saw a doctor, and it turned out to be a herniated disc. It was a bit of a wake-up call for me. I had to take a few weeks off work to focus on physical therapy and rest, which was tough because I was used to being so active and involved in my community. It was frustrating at first, but it also gave me the chance to slow down and really focus on my recovery. I started incorporating more stretching into my routine, and I made sure to take breaks during the day to avoid sitting for too long. It was a reminder that even people who are generally healthy can face unexpected challenges, and it made me more aware of the importance of listening to my body. I'm doing much better now, but I've learned to be more mindful of how I move and sit throughout the day. It's also made me more empathetic toward others who are dealing with chronic pain or injuries—they don't always have the luxury of slowing down, and that's something I try to keep in mind in my work with clients.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Amanda Hollins: It's definitely affected my work in some ways, especially in the beginning when I was dealing with the pain and physical therapy. I had to adjust my schedule, take more breaks, and sometimes I'd have to delegate tasks or ask for support from my team. It was humbling to realize that even though I'm used to being the one who helps others, I needed help too. At first, it was hard to admit that I couldn't do everything on my own, but over time, I learned to lean on my colleagues and friends when I needed to. It also made me more compassionate toward my clients who are dealing with their own health challenges—whether it's chronic pain, mental health struggles, or something else. I think it deepened my understanding of what it means to be resilient and to ask for help when you need it. While it was a tough experience, it ultimately made me a better worker and a better person, and I'm grateful for the lessons it taught me.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Amanda Hollins: Over the past year, I've had a lot of mixed emotions—there's been a lot of growth, but also a lot of challenges. On one hand, I feel more grounded in my work and more confident in the impact I'm making, even if it's slow progress. I've taken on more leadership roles at the nonprofit, which has been both exciting and overwhelming at times. I've also started mentoring some new case managers, which is something I never imagined I'd be doing a few years ago. It's rewarding to see them grow and to know that I can pass on some of the lessons I've learned along the way. On the other hand, the past year has been emotionally heavy. I've seen more people struggling than ever before, especially with the ongoing effects of the pandemic and rising costs of living. It's hard not to feel discouraged sometimes, knowing that the system we're trying to change is so deeply entrenched. But I also feel a deep sense of purpose, and I remind myself that even small victories—like helping someone find stable housing or connect with a support group—matter. I've also been working on my own emotional resilience, which has been a journey. I've started journaling more, and it's helped me process the stress and stay connected to my values. Overall, I feel like I'm in a place where I'm learning to balance the weight of the work with the importance of self-care, and that's something I'm really trying to hold onto.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and daily routines shape my ability to show up for the work I care about so deeply. It's easy to forget that taking care of myself isn't just about being physically healthy—it's also about mental resilience and emotional balance. The recent changes I've made, like incorporating mindfulness and biking to work, remind me that even small actions can contribute to a larger sense of well-being. At the same time, my experience with chronic back pain was a humbling reminder that health challenges can affect anyone, and they don't always come with clear solutions. It made me more empathetic toward others who are dealing with their own struggles, and it also taught me the importance of asking for help when I need it. I've come to see my health not as something separate from my work or my values, but as a foundation that supports everything I do. It's a lesson I carry with me every day, and it's something I hope to pass on to others who are navigating their own paths.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Amanda Hollins: I think I've definitely struggled with anxiety, especially in the past few years as my work has become more demanding and the issues I deal with on a daily basis have felt more overwhelming. It's not something I used to talk about openly, but I've come to realize that acknowledging it is the first step toward managing it. I've started seeing a therapist regularly, which has been really helpful. It's not that I'm depressed, but there are definitely days when the weight of everything feels too heavy to carry. I've learned to recognize the signs—like when I'm constantly on edge, having trouble sleeping, or feeling like I can't focus on anything for more than a few minutes. I've also started practicing mindfulness more consistently, which has helped me stay grounded when things feel chaotic. I don't want to minimize what I'm going through, but I also don't want to let it define me. I've learned that it's okay to not be okay, and that taking care of my mental health is just as important as taking care of my physical health. It's a work in progress, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself and to seek support when I need it.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Amanda Hollins: For my family, it's been a mix of pride and concern. My parents have always been proud of the path I've chosen, especially since it aligns with the values they instilled in me growing up. But they've also been worried about the toll my work takes on me—especially after I dealt with the back injury. They've made it a point to check in on me more often, and my mom even started sending me care packages with things like healthy snacks, yoga mats, and books to help me stay grounded. My sister, on the other hand, has been more of a sounding board for me. She's been going through her own challenges with graduate school and balancing her activism work, so we've had a lot of late-night conversations about how to stay resilient in the face of burnout. It's been tough for them to see me struggle, but they've also been a huge source of strength. They remind me that I'm not alone in this, and that my work—while difficult—is making a real difference. I think they've come to understand that this is who I am, and while they may not always agree with the choices I make, they support me in their own way. It's comforting to know that even when I feel like I'm carrying the weight of the world, my family is there to remind me that I don't have to carry it alone.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Amanda Hollins: I think I've always been more of a spiritual person than a religious one, even though I was raised Protestant. As I got older, I found that the rigid structures and doctrines of organized religion didn't quite resonate with me anymore. What I do believe in, though, is the idea of interconnectedness—the understanding that we're all part of something bigger, whether that's the community, the environment, or the shared human experience. I find meaning in small, everyday moments: the way the sun feels on my skin, the quiet strength of people who keep going despite everything, or the way a simple act of kindness can ripple out and change someone's day. I also think about the values I was taught growing up—things like compassion, integrity, and the importance of helping others—and I try to carry those with me in everything I do. It's not about faith in a higher power for me, but more about faith in the goodness of people and the possibility of change. I think that's why I'm drawn to social justice work—it feels like a way of living out that belief in action.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Amanda Hollins: I use social media, but not in the way a lot of people do. I'm not really into scrolling through endless feeds or comparing my life to others. Instead, I use it as a tool to stay informed and connected to the causes I care about. I follow a lot of local activists, nonprofit organizations, and community leaders in Austin who are doing important work in social justice, housing, and education. I also use Instagram to share some of the stories I come across in my work—like client success stories or moments of hope that remind me why I keep going. It's not always easy to share those stories, because some of them are really heavy, but I think it's important to highlight the resilience of the people I work with. I also use Facebook to stay in touch with family and old friends, especially since I'm not always around for big family events. I try to be intentional about how I use these platforms, though—I set limits on how much time I spend online, and I make sure it's not taking away from my mental health or my work. At the end of the day, I see social media as a way to amplify voices that need to be heard, not as a distraction from the real work that needs to be done.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Amanda Hollins: Honestly, I haven't relied much on social media for emotional or financial support during tough times, but I can see how it might help others. For me, it's more about staying connected to the community and the work I care about. That said, there have been moments when I've turned to online forums or support groups for people in similar fields—like social workers or activists—where we can share experiences and advice. It's not the same as having someone physically there, but it does provide a sense of solidarity. I think the biggest support I've gotten has come from my close friends, my family, and even some of my colleagues at the nonprofit. They've been there to listen, offer advice, or just remind me that I'm not alone in this. I don't think I'd have made it through some of the harder times without them.

Going through the questions about my health and emotional well-being has made me reflect on how deeply intertwined my physical and mental health are with the work I do. It's easy to forget that taking care of others starts with taking care of myself, and the past year has been a reminder of that. My experience with chronic back pain was a wake-up call—I had to slow down and listen to my body, which was hard because I'm used to being so active and driven. But it also taught me the importance of rest, recovery, and asking for help when I need it. At the same time, dealing with anxiety and the emotional weight of my job has been challenging, but I've learned that it's okay not to be okay all the time. I've started seeing a therapist, practicing mindfulness, and journaling more, which have all helped me stay grounded. I've also come to realize that my family and friends have been a huge source of support, even when I didn't always ask for it. It's comforting to know that I'm not alone in this, and that the people around me care about my well-being. These experiences have shaped me in ways I didn't expect, and I'm trying to carry those lessons forward—not just in my work, but in how I show up for myself and others every day.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Amanda Hollins: In the past few months, I've noticed my stress levels have shifted—there's been a bit more of a balance, but also some new challenges. I think part of it is that I've started to lean more into my coping strategies, like mindfulness and journaling, which have become more than just habits—they're now part of my daily rhythm. I've also been more open about my emotions with friends and colleagues, which has helped me feel less isolated. That said, there are still days when the weight of the work feels overwhelming, especially when I see clients who are struggling with things I can't always fix. What's changed for me is how I respond to that stress. Instead of trying to push through it all on my own, I've started to ask for help more often, whether it's from my therapist, my friends, or even just taking a few minutes to breathe when I feel my anxiety creeping in. I've also found that setting boundaries—like limiting my work hours and making sure I have time for rest—has made a real difference. It's not perfect, but I feel like I'm learning to navigate my emotions in a way that's more sustainable, and that gives me a little more hope for the future.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Amanda Hollins: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and transportation. I live in a small apartment in East Austin, and the rent is pretty steep for the size and location, especially with the rising cost of living here. I try to keep it manageable by sticking to a strict budget, but it's still a significant chunk of my income. Groceries are another big one—since I cook at home most of the time, I try to buy in bulk and focus on healthy, affordable options, but it still adds up, especially when I have to buy fresh produce or specialty items for clients I'm working with. Transportation is also a challenge. While I bike to work a few times a week, I still rely on the bus or rideshares on other days, and those costs can add up, especially when I'm working late or have to travel to different parts of the city for meetings. I also set aside money for my therapy sessions and yoga classes, which I consider essential for my well-being. I've had to be really careful with my spending, and sometimes I have to make tough choices, like skipping a meal out or delaying a purchase, just to stay on track. It's not always easy, but I remind myself that every dollar I save helps me stay focused on the work I do, and that gives me a sense of purpose even when the budget is tight.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Amanda Hollins: In the past month, my household spent roughly around $2,800, which is actually a bit lower than my usual monthly spending. Typically, I spend closer to $3,000 to $3,200, depending on how many times I need to use rideshares or if I have to buy anything extra for work-related events or client support. The majority of that goes to rent, which is about $1,400 a month, and groceries, which usually run me around $600 to $700. Transportation is another big chunk—around $300 to $400, including bus passes, bike maintenance, and occasional rideshares. I also set aside about $200 for my therapy sessions and yoga classes, which I consider non-negotiable for my mental health. The rest goes toward utilities, personal care, and a small savings fund. I've been trying to be more intentional with my spending, especially since I know how much of my income goes toward basic needs. It's not always easy, but I remind myself that every dollar I save helps me stay focused on the work I do, and that gives me a sense of purpose even when the budget is tight.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Amanda Hollins: We rent our home. I live in a small apartment in East Austin, which is convenient for my job but definitely comes with its challenges. Rent is one of the biggest expenses in my budget, and it's something I have to be really careful with. I've been in the same apartment for about two years now, and while I love the location and the sense of community here, I know that housing costs in Austin are pretty high compared to other places. I've considered moving to a different part of the city or even a smaller town to save money, but I keep coming back to the fact that East Austin is where I feel most connected to the work I do. It's a tough balance, but I think it's worth it for the opportunities and the people here. I also know that renting means I don't have the long-term stability of homeownership, which is something I might think about in the future if my financial situation changes.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Amanda Hollins: Over the past year, my bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons and the different events that come up. For example, during the winter months, my utility bills—especially heating—go up a bit, and I have to budget for that. I also noticed that during the holidays, my grocery expenses increase because I tend to buy more fresh produce and ingredients for meals I make for friends or for clients I'm supporting. There's also the cost of transportation, which can vary depending on how much I travel for work meetings or community events. In the summer, I use the bus more often because biking in the heat isn't always practical, and that adds a bit more to my monthly transportation costs. Another thing that affects my budget is the timing of my therapy sessions and yoga classes—sometimes I have to adjust my schedule or pay for extra sessions if I'm feeling more overwhelmed, which can push my monthly expenses a little higher. Overall, it's been a bit of a rollercoaster, but I've learned to plan ahead and set aside a little extra each month for these fluctuations. It's not always perfect, but it helps me stay on track and not get caught off guard when things change.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply my family and emotional well-being are connected to the work I do. It's humbling to realize how much my parents and sister have supported me, even when I didn't always ask for it, and how their concern has reminded me to take care of myself. At the same time, I've come to understand that my mental health isn't something I can ignore—it's a part of who I am and how I show up for others. While I don't rely on social media for emotional support, I've found strength in the real, in-person connections I have with friends, colleagues, and my family. These experiences have reinforced the idea that we all need support in our own ways, and that asking for help isn't a weakness, but a sign of strength. I'm grateful for the people in my life who remind me of that, and I hope to continue being a source of support for others, just as they've been for me.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Amanda Hollins: I do save, though it's not always easy given my budget. I have a small savings account that I try to contribute to every month, even if it's just a few hundred dollars. It's more of a safety net than anything else, just in case something unexpected comes up—like a sudden medical expense or a need to cover rent if I ever have a gap in income. I also try to save in other ways, like setting aside a portion of my income for things like professional development or courses that could help me advance in my career. It's not a lot, but I think it's important to have some financial cushion, even if it's just a little. I've learned that saving doesn't have to be about huge amounts—it's about consistency and making sure I'm not living paycheck to paycheck. I also try to be mindful of my spending habits, like avoiding impulse purchases or eating out too often, so that I can put more money toward savings. It's not perfect, but I feel like I'm making progress, and that gives me a little more peace of mind.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Amanda Hollins: In the last year, I've been saving more for a rainy day than for any big purchases like a home. Honestly, buying a home feels pretty far off right now, especially with the way housing prices have gone up in Austin. I've been focusing on building a small emergency fund, just in case something unexpected comes up—like a sudden medical expense or a need to cover rent if I ever have a gap in income. I also try to save a little bit each month for professional development, like workshops or courses that could help me advance in my career or learn new skills. It's not a lot, but I think it's important to have some financial cushion, even if it's just a little. I've learned that saving doesn't have to be about huge amounts—it's about consistency and making sure I'm not living paycheck to paycheck. I also try to be mindful of my spending habits, like avoiding impulse purchases or eating out too often, so that I can put more money toward savings. It's not perfect, but I feel like I'm making progress, and that gives me a little more peace of mind.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Amanda Hollins: My occupation is a case manager at a nonprofit organization called Austin Hope Alliance, and it's one of the most meaningful roles I've ever had. As a case manager, my primary responsibilities involve working directly with individuals and families who are experiencing homelessness, domestic violence, or other crises. I meet with clients regularly to assess their needs, create personalized support plans, and connect them with resources like housing assistance, mental health services, and job training programs. One of the most important parts of my job is building trust with my clients—many of them have been through a lot, and they need someone they can rely on. I also coordinate with other departments within the organization, like legal aid or healthcare partners, to make sure clients get the full range of support they need. The most challenging part of the job is seeing the systemic barriers that keep people stuck in cycles of poverty and instability, but it's also incredibly rewarding to be part of someone's journey toward stability, even if it's just a small step. I think what keeps me going is knowing that even though the work is tough, it's making a real difference in people's lives.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Amanda Hollins: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the time of year and the needs of my clients. Some weeks are busier than others, especially when we're coordinating with other organizations or preparing for community outreach events. I try to stick to a standard 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. schedule, but I often end up staying late a few days a week to wrap up reports or meet with clients who need extra support. I've learned to be flexible with my time, but I also make it a point to set boundaries so I can recharge. It's not always easy, especially when I see clients who are in really tough situations, but I remind myself that I can only do so much, and that taking care of myself is part of the job too.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Amanda Hollins: Yes, I actually do have a part-time gig on the weekends as a freelance writer for a few local community publications and advocacy groups. It started as a way to stay connected to the issues I care about and to keep my creative side engaged, especially since my full-time job can be so emotionally intense. I usually write articles or op-eds on topics related to social justice, housing, and mental health, and it's been a great way to share stories that might not always get told. I work about 10 to 15 hours a week on these projects, mostly on weekends or evenings after work. It's not a huge income boost, but it helps me feel more balanced and gives me a different kind of fulfillment. Plus, it allows me to use my voice in ways that complement my case management work. I've also been thinking about expanding into more digital content, like blog posts or social media campaigns, to reach a wider audience. It's a small part of my life, but it adds another layer to how I contribute to the causes I believe in.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my emotional well-being and financial stability are intertwined with the work I do. It's been a journey to find balance between the demands of my job, my mental health, and my budget, and I've learned that none of these areas exist in isolation. The past few months have shown me that managing stress and worry isn't just about finding coping strategies—it's about being intentional with how I show up for myself and others. I've also come to appreciate how my family and close friends have been a constant source of support, even when I didn't always ask for it. Their presence reminds me that I don't have to carry everything alone, and that's something I try to pass on to the people I work with. At the same time, navigating my monthly budget has been a humbling experience. It's not always easy to make ends meet, especially in a city like Austin where the cost of living is so high, but I've learned to be more mindful of my spending and to prioritize what truly matters. These reflections have helped me see that my well-being—both emotional and financial—is a foundation that supports everything I do, and I'm trying to hold onto that understanding as I move forward.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Amanda Hollins: In total, my household made around $3,200 in the past month. That comes from my full-time job as a case manager and my part-time freelance writing gigs. It's not a huge amount, especially when you factor in the cost of living here in Austin, but it's enough to cover my rent, groceries, transportation, and a few other essentials. I've been trying to be really mindful of how I spend my money, especially since I know how much of my income goes toward basic needs. I also set aside a small portion each month for savings, even if it's just a few hundred dollars. It's not always easy, but I remind myself that every dollar I save helps me stay focused on the work I do, and that gives me a sense of purpose even when the budget is tight.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Amanda Hollins: I've been at Austin Hope Alliance for about three and a half years now, and it's been a journey of growth both personally and professionally. The benefits of the job are pretty standard for a nonprofit—health insurance is one of the biggest ones, though it's not always the most comprehensive, especially when it comes to mental health coverage. I've had to supplement that with my own therapy plan, which I think is something a lot of people in my field deal with. We do get paid time off, which is something I really appreciate, especially during the busier months when I need to take a step back and recharge. We also have some flexibility with our schedules, which helps when I need to adjust for client needs or personal commitments. One of the things I value most is the sense of purpose that comes with the job. Even though the pay isn't huge and the benefits aren't always perfect, I feel like I'm making a real difference in people's lives, and that's something I can't put a price on.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Amanda Hollins: My relationships at work are pretty collaborative and supportive, even though the environment can be intense at times. I have a good relationship with my manager, Sarah, who I think genuinely cares about her team and the impact we make. She's been a great mentor to me, especially in the early days of my career, and she's always encouraged me to take on more responsibility when I'm ready. I admire her dedication and the way she leads with empathy, even when the workload is heavy. As for my coworkers, we have a strong sense of camaraderie. We all know the challenges of the work we do, and that creates a kind of unspoken bond. We support each other through the tough days, whether it's by covering for someone who's overwhelmed or just checking in to see how someone is doing. There's a lot of trust and mutual respect, which is important in a field where we're dealing with people's most vulnerable moments. I think that's one of the reasons I've stayed at the organization for so long—it's not just about the work, but the people I get to do it with.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Amanda Hollins: My work schedule is pretty predictable in terms of core hours, but there's definitely a lot of flexibility depending on the needs of my clients and the organization. I usually start at 8:30 a.m. and end at 5:00 p.m., but I often stay late a few days a week to wrap up reports or meet with clients who need extra support. The flexibility is both a blessing and a challenge. On one hand, it allows me to be responsive to the people I work with, which is important when their situations are urgent or evolving. On the other hand, it can make it harder to set clear boundaries between work and personal time. I've learned to be intentional about when I leave the office and how I manage my time outside of work, but it's not always easy. There are days when I need to adjust my schedule last minute for a client meeting or a community event, and that can throw off my routine. Still, I think the flexibility is worth it because it allows me to be present for the people I serve, even if it means sacrificing some predictability in my own life.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Amanda Hollins: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is manageable, but it's definitely a tightrope walk. I'm not struggling, but I also know I'm not in a position of financial security. I make enough to cover my basic needs and a small savings, but I'm always aware of how quickly things can shift—whether it's a medical bill, a sudden increase in rent, or a period where my freelance work dries up. I've learned to be really intentional with every dollar I earn, and I take pride in the fact that I'm not living paycheck to paycheck. Still, there are moments when I look at my budget and feel the weight of how much it costs to live in a city like Austin, especially when I see people in my community who are struggling even more than I am. It's a constant reminder that while I have a stable job and a support system, there's always room for growth, and I'm trying to be proactive about building more financial resilience over time.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Amanda Hollins: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My mom was a teacher, and she worked full-time at a local school for over 20 years. She always said that education was the key to opportunity, and she lived by that belief every day. My dad worked in management for a small business, and he was always passionate about helping others, whether it was through his work or his volunteer efforts. He used to say that everyone deserves a second chance, and I think that belief really shaped me. Having both of them working full-time meant that our household had a stable income, and I never had to worry about basic needs. It also meant that I saw the value of hard work and dedication from an early age, which is something I carry with me in my own career today.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Amanda Hollins: My mom was a teacher, and her most important activities involved not just teaching academics, but also nurturing the minds and hearts of her students. She had a way of making every child feel seen and valued, and she often stayed after school to help students who were struggling or needed extra support. She believed that education was more than just reading, writing, and arithmetic—it was about opening doors and giving people the tools to build better lives. My dad, on the other hand, worked in management for a small business, but his job wasn't just about numbers and operations. He was deeply committed to creating a positive work environment for his employees, and he often went out of his way to support people in his team, whether it was offering flexible hours or helping them with personal challenges. He used to say that leadership wasn't just about authority—it was about empathy and lifting others up. Watching them both work with such purpose and compassion really shaped my own values and the kind of work I wanted to do in the world.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Amanda Hollins: My mom worked at a local public school in our small town, and it was a place where she truly believed in the power of education to transform lives. She taught middle school English, but her role went far beyond the classroom. She was the kind of teacher who stayed late to help students with their essays, who organized after-school tutoring sessions, and who even wrote recommendation letters for kids who were applying to college. She made sure that every student felt like they had a chance, no matter their background. My dad worked for a small family-owned business that provided management and consulting services to other local companies. He wasn't just focused on profits—he was always looking for ways to support his employees and the community. He would often take on extra work to help someone in need, whether it was a struggling employee or a neighbor who needed a hand. He had this saying: 'You don't have to be rich to be generous.' Watching them both work with such purpose and integrity really shaped the kind of person I wanted to become.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Amanda Hollins: I hope that in a few years, I'm still doing work that feels meaningful and that I'm making a real difference in people's lives, even if the path looks a little different. I'd love to have more stability in my career—maybe taking on a leadership role within the nonprofit or even starting my own initiative that focuses on long-term solutions for homelessness and housing insecurity. I also hope that I'm in a better financial position, not just for myself, but so that I can support others more effectively. I want to be someone who can advocate for systemic change without constantly worrying about rent or bills. On a personal level, I hope I'm still living in East Austin, surrounded by the community that inspires me, and that I'm still growing in ways I never expected. I also hope that I'm more balanced—still passionate about my work, but also taking better care of myself, whether that means more time for rest, more time with family, or even more time for the little things that bring me joy, like reading, cooking, or just sitting in the sun with a good book. I think the most important thing is that I'm still true to who I am and the values I was raised with—compassion, integrity, and the belief that everyone deserves a chance to thrive.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Amanda Hollins: What I value the most in my life is connection—both to people and to the work that matters. I think it's easy to get caught up in the hustle of daily life, but what keeps me grounded is the relationships I have with my family, my friends, and the people I work with. I value the trust that my clients place in me, even when their lives are in chaos, and I value the support my loved ones give me, even when I don't always ask for it. I also value the small, everyday moments that bring me joy—like the smell of fresh coffee in the morning, the sound of rain on the windows, or the quiet satisfaction of cooking a meal from scratch. But above all, I value the belief that we can all make a difference, no matter how small our actions seem. I think that's what keeps me going, even on the hardest days.
